arm_group.description: Patients admitted to ICU after surgery, treated with mechanical ventilation, sedated and paralized

arm_group.arm_group_label: Postsurgical patients intubated and breathing spontaneously

brief_summary.textblock:
Esophageal pressure measurement, obtained with the use of an esophageal balloon catheter, is
      fundamental to assess mechanical characteristics of the respiratory system during mechanical
      ventilation. The correct positioning of the catheter (usually at the medium third of the
      esophagus) is crucial for an accurate measurement of esophageal pressure. Usually the
      correct positioning of the catheter is verified with an occlusion test (If the patient is
      breathing spontaneously) or with thoraco-abdominal compressions (if the patient is sedated
      and paralyzed). Aim of this study is to compare the accuracy of these two methods at
      different PEEP and esophageal catheter positions.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Two Tests in the Assessment of the Accuracy of Esophageal Pressure Variations Measurement During Mechanical Ventilation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Mechanical ventilation for clinical purposes

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Hemodynamic instability

          -  Esophageal diseases

          -  Refusal of the patient

intervention.description: Occlusion test to assess the correct positioning of esophageal balloon catheter when the patient is breathing spontaneously.
